testCases.explanation: With k=2 (implicit): element 1 has 3 greater (2,3,4>=2), element 2 has 2 greater (3,4>=2). Elements 3 and 4 have fewer than 2 greater. Count=2.
All elements are equal, no element has any greater value. Count=0.

With k=2: element 1 has 4 greater, element 2 has 3 greater, element 3 has 2 greater, element 4 has 1 greater, element 5 has 0. Elements with >= 2 greater: 1,2,3 â†’ count=3. Actually with k=3: 1 has 4>=3, 2 has 3>=3. Count=2.
Single element has no elements greater than it. Count=0.
With k=1: element 1 has 1 greater (which is 2), element 2 has 0 greater. Count=1.

description: Given an integer array `nums`, count the number of elements that have at least k elements greater than them in the array. Here k is determined by the context of the problem (typically k = floor(n/2) or a fixed constant).

examples.explanation: With k=2: elements 1 and 2 each have at least 2 elements greater.
No element has any greater value.
